item.title: Airstrikes Take Toll on Civilians in Yemen War
item.description: A Saudi-led aerial campaign against the Houthis, a rebel militia movement, has become so broad and vicious that critics accuse the coalition of collectively punishing people living in areas the Houthis control.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Airstrikes Take Toll on Civilians in Yemen War
item.description: What began as a Saudi-led aerial campaign against the Houthis, a rebel militia movement, has become so broad and vicious that critics accuse the coalition of collectively punishing people living in areas the Houthis control.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Premier Quits With Cabinet, Roiling Egypt
item.description: With parliamentary elections looming, the prime minister and his cabinet step down amid a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: JARED MALSIN

item.title: A Hunting Ban Saps a Village’s Livelihood
item.description: Villages like Sankuyo, Botswana, have lost income from trophy hunting while growing numbers of lions and elephants threaten their livestock and crops. Many in Africa argue that Western sensitivities are actually hurting conservation efforts.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Top left, Andy Loveridge/Wildlife Conservation Research Unit, via Associated Press; photographs by Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Cecil, a lion whose death at the hands of a hunter in Zimbabwe sparked calls for curbs on trophy hunting across Africa; William Moalosi, a farmer and former hunting guide in Sankuyo, Botswana; an elephant in Botswana; and Othusitse Ndozi in Sankuyo, a village that used to get a steady income from hunting.

item.title: In Pakistan, U.S. Aid Agency’s Efforts Produce Dubious Results
item.description: Critics accuse the United States Agency for International Development of, among other things, taking on projects with little concern for local priorities.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ
item.media:description: Pakistani workers at a fruit market in Lahore. Critics say American aid in the country has had minimal impact on the ground.

item.title: Dispatch: Why Russians Hate America. Again.
item.description: Back after a decade away, a reporter finds more wealth — and loathing.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: A Russian politician, Alexei Didenko, took an ice-bucket challenge in Moscow in 2014 to protest what he called “anti-Russian American propaganda.”

item.title: News Analysis: Are Western Values Losing Their Sway?
item.description: The global embrace of liberal democracy is far from inevitable.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Explosion in India Town Kills Dozens
item.description: The blast, which killed at least 89 people, occurred in a shop carrying explosives in Petlawad, in the state of Madhya Pradesh, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: An explosion rocked a town in Madhya Pradesh, India, on Saturday, killing dozens.

item.title: Body of U.S. Tourist in Spain Is Found, and Arrest Is Made
item.description: The body Denise Thiem was found after months of investigation and with the help of search dogs, helicopters and more than 300 police and military officers.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Editorial: Northern Ireland Must Resist Pull of the Past
item.description: A crisis that threatens to collapse the government could bring about a prolonged political struggle or even a return to widespread violence.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: The funeral of Kevin McGuigan, a former Irish Republican Army member, on Aug. 18 in Belfast.

item.title: Investigations Stymied in Malaysia, Critics of Najib Razak Take Their Case Global
item.description: Opponents of the prime minister are prodding foreign governments and agencies to look into allegations of graft and money laundering related to the his personal financial accounts.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia, center, at National Day celebrations in Kuala Lumpur, in August. His opponents are prodding foreign governments and agencies to investigate allegations of graft and money laundering.

item.title: Eastern Bloc’s Resistance to Refugees Highlights Europe’s Cultural and Political Divisions
item.description: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Soldiers and police pursued a migrant who crossed a border fence into Hungary on Saturday. The nation is sharply resisting the recent influx of migrants.

item.title: With Jeremy Corbyn Elected as New Leader, Britain’s Labour Party Takes a Hard Left Turn
item.description: With the elevation of Mr. Corbyn, the Labour Party is in the hands of the hard left for the first time in decades.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn after being elected leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party on Saturday.

item.title: Police Officer Beaten to Death in Nepal Amid Protests Over Draft Constitution
item.description: An injured riot police officer was dragged from an ambulance by a crowd of ethnic Madhesis in Mahottari District protesting a plan to carve out seven federal provinces.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Singapore Voters Give Ruling Party a Resounding Victory
item.description: The long-governing People’s Action Party claimed nearly 70 percent of the vote, recovering from its worst showing ever four years ago.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Singaporeans arriving to vote at a polling station in Singapore on Friday.

item.title: Singapore Polls Open in Election Seen as Referendum on Ruling Party
item.description: Whether the governing party picks up the seats it lost in 2011 or loses even more will determine whether voters want it to maintain its dominance in politics.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Singaporeans arriving to vote at a polling station in Singapore on Friday.

item.title: Lack of Respect for Obama Emboldened Putin, Donald Trump Tells Ukrainians
item.description: Via video link, the Republican presidential candidate told Ukrainians at a conference that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia felt free to invade Crimea and eastern Ukraine because he lacks respect for President Obama.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Opposition in Venezuela Is Unsettled by Leader’s Sentence
item.description: Only a few hundred people showed up to support Leopoldo López, a day after he was convicted and sentenced to nearly 14 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a demonstration in Caracas on Friday, Lilian Tintori read a letter that her husband, Leopoldo López, an opposition leader, had written in prison.

item.title: Police Offer Beaten to Death in Nepal Amid Protests Over Draft Constitution
item.description: An injured riot police officer was dragged from an ambulance by a crowd of ethnic Madhesis in Mahottari District protesting a plan to carve out seven federal provinces.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: News Analysis: Nuclear Deal Sealed, Obama Must Now Make It Work, and Mend Fences
item.description: Supporters and critics alike said Mr. Obama must detail how the United States and other world powers intend to enforce and monitor the nuclear agreement with Iran.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
